name: Conway's thrackle conjecture
summary: Conway's thrackle conjecture is a still-unsolved problem in graph theory that states any thrackle, a drawing of a graph where every pair of edges meets exactly once (either at a shared vertex or a proper crossing), can have no more edges than vertices. If true, this would imply that thrackleable graphs are relatively simple, with each connected component containing at most one cycle.
head: A graph \(G\) has a drawing in the plane that is a thrackle (meaning every pair of edges meets exactly once, either at a common endpoint or a proper crossing).
tail: The number of edges of \(G\) is less than or equal to the number of its vertices (\(|E(G)|\le |V(G)|\)).Â
